newsitem.title: UK: RTRS-FOCUS-Nazi gold return talk fails to excite Gold market.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-FOCUS-Nazi gold return talk fails to excite Gold market.

text.p: The bullion market ignored speculation over the fate of gold looted by Nazi Germany, since any return of gold held by Switzerland would be complicated and time consuming, analysts said.
"No-one's talking about it. These guys will argue about it for years," said Ted Arnold, metals analyst at broker Merrill Lynch.

The gold price, hovering around $383 per ounce, has barely moved since Britain disclosed in a report on Tuesday that Switzerland only turned over to Allied powers a small fraction of the gold it acknowledged buying in World War Two.
This spurred the Jewish community to renew calls on Switzerland to restore stolen gold to Nazi survivors and their descendants.
"The pure logistics of tracing the original holders would be such that if anything is done it is going to take forever and a day," said Rhona O'Connell, metals analyst at broker T. Hoare and Company.

"Now If I were a private individual who stood to inherit a half a tonne of gold I might well be tempted to sell some of it, but the prospects of that happening in the foreseeable future have to be nil to zero," she added.

The British report, citing a U.S. government account, said that the director of the Swiss National Bank said during post-war negotiations with the Allies that Swiss banks held $500 million of gold when the war ended -- $6.5 billion at today's prices.
Gold prices have been steadily crumbling since a frenzied rally pushed the market to six-year highs around $418 per ounce in February.

Over the past few weeks, speculators have been disappointed that U.S. strikes on Iraq have failed to rouse the market and are fearing the International Monetary Fund may approve a plan on Friday to sell some of its bullion reserves to finance aid to poor countries.
